title: New feature in object category: findKeyDeep
Load all Lodash modules
body:
I've created a modularized version of Lodash using lodash-cli:

    lodash exports=amd,node,global --output lodash modularize

This works great when I want to load a few functions individually but there are some cases where I want to load the entire library. Is there a way to compile something like lodash/index.js or lodash/lodash.js (similar to the one created by npm) which loads all the lodash modules into a single export? Currently I'm running a second command which works but not ideal.

    lodash exports=amd,node,global --output lodash/lodash.js core

title: Document that get supports arrays
body:
_.get appears to support arrays fine, but it is undocumented.
It is useful if navigating through an object structure containing arrays.

title: _.words and the single quote/apostrophe character (')
body:
In many orthographies, the apostrophe, despite not being part of the alphabet, is used as a letter, by which I mean it is considered part of the word, not a punctuation mark. E.g. Ukrainian:
```js
_.words(`Кам'янець-Подільський`); // ["Кам", "янець", "Подільський"]
```
Expected: `["Кам'янець", "Подільський"]`

I see there has been implemented a special-case handling for English contractions like "isn't" and"aren't", but in all other cases, `_.words` treats an apostrophe in the middle of a word as a word separator (punctuation). Why is it so? I'm rather surprised by this behavior because I can't see how it's useful.

title: Feature: Shorthand for `overArgs`
body:
Recently, I found the exceptionally useful function `overArgs` (thank you to @steelsojka for [suggesting and implementing `useWith` in 2015!](/lodash/lodash/issues/1235)). Function argument transformation is something that crossed my mind a lot of times before realizing it already exists in lodash—the greatest function library of all time (mandatory butt-kissing dealt with).

I've found some great uses for this utility but I'd really like to see a shorthand version introduced. More often than not when writing functional-style code, the transformation I want to do is actually the same for all parameters.

I'll give an example. Consider I have a helpful utility for finding the quotient of a division:
```javascript
import { pipe, divide, floor } from 'lodash/fp';

export const quotient = pipe(divide, floor);
```
But what I actually want to do is find the quotient between the lengths of two arrays. So I create a new utility using `overArgs` to transform the parameters from arrays into array lengths that the `quotient` function can understand:
```javascript
export const sizeQuotient = overArgs(quotient, [size, size]);
```

And suddenly I can do magic: like easily determining the chunk size when dividing the items in an array between the members of another array:
```javascript
trees; // ['American Hornbeam', 'Black Oak', 'White Oak', 'Red Maple', 'Pin Cherry', 'Paper Birch', 'White Ash', 'Tulip Tree', 'Yellow Birch', 'Shagbark Hickory', 'Pignut Hickory', 'American Beech', 'Butternut', 'Shadbush', 'Sugar Maple', 'Black Locust'];
groups; // ['Yellow', 'Red', 'Blue', 'Green'];

const chunkSize = sizeQuotient(trees, groups);
const members = chunk(chunkSize, trees);
const result = zipObject(groups, members);
```
Resulting in a list of trees divided in to nice, even groups by colour:
```javascript
{
  Yellow: ['American Hornbeam', 'Black Oak', 'White Oak', 'Red Maple'], 
  Red: ['Pin Cherry', 'Paper Birch', 'White Ash', 'Tulip Tree'], 
  Blue: ['Yellow Birch', 'Shagbark Hickory', 'Pignut Hickory', 'American Beech'],
  Green: ['Butternut', 'Shadbush', 'Sugar Maple', 'Black Locust'],
}
```

I really enjoy how expressive this is, but one tiny thing is bothering me: having to specify an array of transformations with the same transformation specified twice. When I go back to optimize, I take a guess and change the `sizeQuotient` utility to:
```javascript
overArgs(quotient, size)
```
Which doesn't blow up but only transforms the first parameter. After a quick look at the source code, I can see that `overArgs` uses `baseFlatten` to cast a single non-array parameter into an array with a length of 1.

I'm proposing we change this so that the length of the array is defined by `func.length` (not unlike how `createWrap` chooses a default arity).

This would mean usages where an array of transformations are provided or a single transformation is provided over a function with a single argument would be completely unaffected.

The only changes in behavior for existing usages would be if a single transformation, not wrapped in an array, is provided for a function with more than one parameter. And since passing a single function isn't currently documented and using `overArgs` like this seems confusingly implicit, I don't think that's a very common usage at all.

@jdalton This request probably won't get a lot of interest because I expect `overArgs` isn't very common in the wild. But I'm absolutely happy to make the small change required, update the documentation and tests, and submit a PR if this is an idea you like.

title: deprecate modular build packages?
body:
I recently discovered that all of the `lodash.assign`, `lodash.isstring`, `lodash.isobject`, etc. packages I've been using were larger than I would have expected, and take up quite a bit of space in my webpack bundles, and that I could save plenty of space by requiring `lodash/assign`, `lodash/isString`, etc. instead.  It seems like all libraries that depend on modular build packages should make this switch.  Deprecating would encourage library authors to get the ball rolling on this change.  (I have my own `jscodeshift` script I've been using to make this change to my own packages and would be happy to release it publically).

Or is there something I misunderstand?  Do the modular build packages really have any advantages over `lodash` anymore?

title: [enhancement] implicit casting within 'maskSrcKey' func
body:
Hi,
i use runtime checks for Array objects (via Symbol.toPrimitive) to prevent some kinds of type errors.
Function
```
var maskSrcKey = (function() {
  var uid = /[^.]+$/.exec(coreJsData && coreJsData.keys && coreJsData.keys.IE_PROTO || '');
  return uid ? ('Symbol(src)_1.' + uid) : '';
}());
```
uses implicit casting - ```('Symbol(src)_1.' + uid)``` - so i have an error message in console:
```
TypeError: implicit coercion:  ["csrbs9spgt", index: 19, input: "Symbol(IE_PROTO)_2.csrbs9spgt", groups: undefined]
```
(you can see it on https://test.cognita.ru/contacts page)

Is there any possibility to rewrite function with explicit ```String(uid)``` usage or with getting the value by index?

**npm package**: lodash.merge
**version**: 4.6.1

title: _.get returns null when value at path is 0 or false
body:
falsy values returns null. Is it a normal behaviour?
It is a real problem when storing 0 (zero) integer or booleans:
```
const foo = {a: 0, b: 1, c: '0', d: false};
_.get(foo, 'd'); // null
_.get(foo, 'a'); // null
```

title: Different implementation of `findIndex` under 4.10.17 and 4.10.17-npm tags
body:
I found out that `findIndex` under 4.10.17-npm tag uses [baseIteratee](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.10-npm/findIndex.js#L52) while under 4.10.17 tag it is [getIteratee](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.10/lodash.js#L7258). While `getIteratee` returns a function, `baseIteratee` returns unmodified value and the subsequent call to `baseFindIndex` errors out because it expects `predicate` arg to be a function:

![](https://i.imgur.com/kqh6sQs.png)
![](https://i.imgur.com/sDMhXNb.png)

Maybe `findIndex` in just did not get updated somehow?

title: difference between different casing imports in lodash
body:
Hi, 

I am trying to use the import per function used approach to use lodash as follows -

(all inside `app.js`)
**Method 1**
```
import _isPlainObject from 'lodash/isplainobject';
```
(referring to https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash.isplainobject)

**Method 2**
```
import _isPlainObject from 'lodash/isPlainObject';
```
Suprisingly both work but,
By using **method 1** i get the WARNING when building using webpack as follows
```
WARNING in ./~/lodash/isPlainObject.js
There are multiple modules with names that only differ in casing.
This can lead to unexpected behavior when compiling on a filesystem with other case-semantic.
Use equal casing. Compare these module identifiers:
* ~/node_modules/lodash/isPlainObject.js
    Used by 1 module(s), i. e.
   ~/node_modules/lodash/_baseMergeDeep.js
* ~/node_modules/lodash/isplainobject.js
    Used by 1 module(s), i. e.
    ~/node_modules/babel-loader/lib/index.js??ref--0!/~/app.js
```
Though under `node_modules/lodash` i see the target function present as `isPlainObject.js`.

SO i am bit confused which is the correct way to import a single function with all lowercasing or camelCasing?? As in what is lodash's recommended way of doing it.
Also if the file name under node_modules is camelCased then how importing the lowercased file also still works??

Thanks.

I have this array, and i would like remove duplicate object using property id, but some times this value is not present in the object

 let array = [{
        "quantity": 1,
        "stockMvtDate": "2018-05-29 05:39:00.000",
        "mvtType": "Reception",
        "id": "1234"
    }, 
  {
        "quantity": 1,
        "stockMvtDate": "2018-05-29 05:39:00.000",
        "mvtType": "Reception",
        "id": "1234"

        "quantity": 1,
        "stockMvtDate": "2018-05-29 05:40:00.000",
        "mvtType": "Reception"
    },
    {
        "quantity": 1,
        "stockMvtDate": "2018-05-29 05:40:00.000",
        "mvtType": "Reception"

];

[ { quantity: 1,
    stockMvtDate: '2018-05-29 05:39:00.000',
    mvtType: 'Reception',
    id: '1234' },
  { quantity: 1,
    stockMvtDate: '2018-05-29 05:40:00.000',
    mvtType: 'Reception' } ]

    stockMvtDate: '2018-05-29 05:39:00.000',

title: CastArray: Add example for existing array value
body:
### Summary

While reading the examples for `castArray` I noticed that many cases are covered, but not the case in which the given value is already an array. The result seems obvious enough, but for the sake of clarity and a fuller set of example cases I thought I'd add this regardless.

### Testing

As this is just an example, no actual testing is necessary. Instead, verify that `_.castArray([1])` does in-fact return `[1]`

See: https://runkit.com/embed/gmnma7sxfajl

title: undefined maxWait on debounce defaults to wait
body:
In the following code, `maxWait` will default to `wait`:
```javascript
const makeOnInputChange = ({wait, maxWait /*, ... */}) => 
   _.debouce(onInputChange, wait, { maxWait });
```
Used with a React component and when `maxWait` comes from the `props`, `maxWait` is often `undefined`. But because of how it's handled in [debounce](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.10/lodash.js#L10323), in this case it defaults to `wait`. 

This is a bit counter intuitive to me, but reading through the code, this seems to be the way options are handled in lodash. I don't know what is the best way, but perhaps it's possible to update the doc to reflect this ?

title: [Feature Request]: toSchemaPath, object to an array of paths
body:
Hi, 

I'm being making some unit test where the test needs to prove an object has the same "schema" than other.
In other words the object must have the same properties that the original in form of a recursive validation.

Actually im using a custom function like this:

```js
var foo1 = {a:1,b:{b1:2,b2:3},c:[{c1:1},{c2:"a"}]}    //original
var foo2 = {a:1,b:{b1:2,b2:3},c:[{c1:1},{c2:"b"}]}   //diferent value
var foo3 = {a:1,b:{b1:2,b2:3},c:[{c1:1},{d2:"a"}]}   //c.d2 doesn't exist
var schema = function(baz,prefix) {
    return _.flattenDeep(_.transform(baz,
    function(r,v,k){
        var scope = (prefix?(prefix+'.'):'') + (_.isInteger(k)?'['+k+']':k) ;
        r.push(scope);
        if(_.isObjectLike(v)){
            r.push(schema(v,scope))
        }
    },
    []))
}
schema(foo1);
_.every(schema(foo1),(val)=>_.has(foo1,val))
_.every(schema(foo1),(val)=>_.has(foo2,val))
_.every(schema(foo1),(val)=>_.has(foo3,val))
```
And in return I have someting like this
```Json
 [ "a", "b", "b.b1", "b.b2", "c", "c.[0]", "c.[0].c1", "c.[1]", "c.[1].c2" ]

true
true
false
```
For me is very useful to validate "schemas" but it can play very nice with 
_.toPath
_.result
_.set
_.update
_.at

title: Excess memory usage - Using _.bind allocates a string with the entire function body
body:
When a function is passed to _.bind, the entire function body becomes stringified. When _.bind is used on large functions or in loops, this can lead to excess and unwanted memory allocation.  In the 99+% case, .toString will never be called on the function & a reference to the function should be kept, not the full string.

Suggestion: Only stringify the "wrapper" function if/when the toString function is invoked.  In my opinion, this functionality isn't actually useful but it's possible that others rely on this behaviour

```javascript

    /**
     * Sets the `toString` method of `wrapper` to mimic the source of `reference`
     * with wrapper details in a comment at the top of the source body.
     *
     * @private
     * @param {Function} wrapper The function to modify.
     * @param {Function} reference The reference function.
     * @param {number} bitmask The bitmask flags. See `createWrap` for more details.
     * @returns {Function} Returns `wrapper`.
     */
    function setWrapToString(wrapper, reference, bitmask) {
      var source = (reference + ''); // This stringifies functions
      return setToString(wrapper, insertWrapDetails(source, updateWrapDetails(getWrapDetails(source), bitmask)));
    }
```

title: Remove apply from memoized function call.
body: It`s possible to call a func without changing its context.

title: Added short circuit for typed arrays
body:
We're using `cloneDeep` for large typed arrays (80k entries or more). We noticed that `cloneDeep` was taking a lot longer than expected for these data sets. After some sleuthing, it looks like the culprit is `baseClone` trying to iterate over the keys of the typed array and copy over its values

We've decided to put in a short circuit clause (not sure if I did it right -- there's probably a slicker way with the `tag` string) to prevent this from happening

We've seen a decrease from 300ms to 3-30ms for 80k entries on an iPad mini

```js
console.time('a');
lodash.cloneDeep(new Float32Array(80e3));
console.timeEnd('a');
```

In this PR:

- Added short circuit for typed arrays

**Notes:**

We'd be happy to write performance tests as well but couldn't seem to find a location to do so

title: mergeDeep does not merge object properties only when customizer function is passed
body:
**What's the problem?**

Docs say that `merge` method recursively merges properties as follows:

> This method is like _.assign except that it recursively merges own and inherited enumerable string keyed properties of source objects into the destination object.

Docs also say that `mergeWith` method is the same with `merge` except that it accepts customizer as follows:

> This method is like _.merge except that it accepts customizer which is invoked to produce the merged values of the destination and source properties. 

So I assume that mergeWith recursively merges properties using customizer.
The assumption is true when the customizer is not passed. However, it stops working recursively when customizer is passed like below:

```
> const {merge, mergeWith} = require('lodash');
> merge({a: [{b: 1, c: 3}]}, {a: [{b: 2, d: 4}]})
{ a: [ { b: 2, c: 3, d: 4 } ] }
> mergeWith({a: [{b: 1, c: 3}]}, {a: [{b: 2, d: 4}]})
{ a: [ { b: 2, c: 3, d: 4 } ] }
> mergeWith({a: [{b: 1, c: 3}]}, {a: [{b: 2, d: 4}]}, (obj, src) => src || obj)
{ a: [ { b: 2, d: 4 } ] }
```

**What do I expect?**

I expect `mergeWith` to recursively merge properties with or without customizer.
I'd like to see the following results:

```
> const {merge, mergeWith} = require('lodash');
> merge({a: [{b: 1, c: 3}]}, {a: [{b: 2, d: 4}]})
{ a: [ { b: 2, c: 3, d: 4 } ] }
> mergeWith({a: [{b: 1, c: 3}]}, {a: [{b: 2, d: 4}]})
{ a: [ { b: 2, c: 3, d: 4 } ] }
> mergeWith({a: [{b: 1, c: 3}]}, {a: [{b: 2, d: 4}]}, (obj, src) => src || obj)
{ a: [ { b: 2, c: 3, d: 4 } ] }
```

title: getOwn function?
body:
Is there a function like `get` but only for own properties?

Currently
```js
> _.get({a: 1}, 'a')
1
> _.get({a: 1}, 'b')
undefined
> _.get({a: 1}, 'toString')
[Function: toString]
> _.has({a: 1}, 'a')
true
> _.has({a: 1}, 'b')
false
> _.has({a: 1}, 'toString')
false
```
so something like
```js
_.has(xs, x) ? _.get(xs, x) : undefined
```
has to be used.

title: behavior about _.snakeCase('h5AsyncRenderUsable')
body:
Is the result `h_5_async_render_usable` right?

I think `h5_async_render_usable` is better.

```
[!] Error: 'default' is not exported by ../../node_modules/lodash/some.js
```

title: `toJSONString` to convert a object to JSON string
body:
Yeah, `JSON.stringify` has already support this feature, while it will throw errors when you try to convert a circular object to a JSON string.
So it's would be better to support this feature in lodash.

title: isArrayLike false detection
body:
`isArrayLike` return `true` when Object has length properties

```
_.isArrayLike({ name: 'video.mp4', length: 26210 });
=> true
```

title: Documentation for create should indicate that prototype is optional
Lodash not working for NodeJS ESM modules
body:
Neither  `import { sum } from 'lodash-es';` or `import { sum } from 'lodash';`.

```
$node -v
v10.0.0
```

```
$ node --experimental-modules test.js
import { sum } from 'lodash-es';
                ^^^
SyntaxError: The requested module 'lodash-es' does not provide an export named 'sum'
```

title: using namespaced packages?
body:
I just tried to install a package:

```
capaj@capaj-i7-4771:~/git_projects/react-timezone-select$ ni lodash.sortBy
npm ERR! code E404
npm ERR! 404 Not Found: lodash.sortBy@latest

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /home/capaj/.npm/_logs/2018-05-02T12_27_54_917Z-debug.log
```

this got me thinking-these packages would be such an easy way to penetrate developer and production machines. Like I could probably just publish that package now and I'd get quite a few people installing the package thinking it is the `lodash.sortby`. If I actually included the functionality, people would get on using it in prod envs for years never realizing that they've got a proxy package, especially If I kept updating it with the official releases.

Wouldn't it make sense to publish the small lodash packages namespaced instead of in public? Like
`@lodash/sortby` instead of the current name?

just a thought. Babel seems to go that route for version 7 so maybe lodash could do the same in version 5?

title: Suggestion: Add pairwise function
body:
I'm working on some map stuff which usually requires to get segments between coordinates. But I found there's no elegant way to complete this with lodash like below:

```` javascript
let points = [[0, 0], [1, 1], [2, 2]]
let segments = points.pairwise((current, next) => new segment(current, next))
````

title: _.sortedIndex question or feature request
body:
I am looking for a method to achieve this

```
const array = [
  { a: { b: 0, c: 2 } },
  { a: { b: 2, c: 5 } },
  { a: { b: 4, c: 3 } },
  { a: { b: 8, c: 7 } }
] // it is sorted by a.b

_.method(array, 3, (obj) => obj.b)) // return 2
```

I would expected a binary search and the result will be similiar to `_.sortedIndex*`. I know I can achieve this with `_.sortedIndexBy(array, { a: { b: 3 } }, "a.b"))`. But I have to create an object. What if the object is too deep?

Is it worth to have this feature? If so, I want to contribute

title: _.zip produces unexpected output
body:
When using the `zip` function on arrays of differing lengths, the standard implementations of `zip` will produce a list which is only as long as the shortest input. lodash appears to always use the longest source array and the output values contain `undefined` where an element does not exist. 

An example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2089820/39196315-65e1185e-47a7-11e8-9b02-5738cfcf9c10.png)  
The expectation in this case would be an output array with only two items.

title: Bug in dropWhile the lodash VERSION = '4.17.5';
Bug in omit fp for deep omit
body:
lodash version : 4.17.5.

When using `omit` from `lodash/fp` on a object, i want to omit a deep attribute in my object, and the source object get mutated. 

example :

```
> const fp = require("lodash/fp")
undefined
> let x = {id: 3, d : [ {id: 4}], j:0}
undefined
> const y = fp.omit(["id","d[0].id"],x)
undefined
> y
{ d: [ {} ], j: 0 }
> x
{ id: 3, d: [ {} ], j: 0 }
>
```

title: Allow compareMultiple/orderBy to accept compare functions
The case for custom compare function for sorting
Import packages for browsers?
body:
So, my initial problem: I want a "per method package", but for browsers. So I think I can choose the "ES6" version.

A solution I have in mind:
Browsers are going to [adopt the import/export modules](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/import) thing as a native implementation, so that may be a future thing to do. But that's still very new.

So, can you package "per method package" also for the browser and not only for npm?

I also tried to download the npm module and use it in a browser, but apparently it is made for npm.

----

BTW I drafted this issue again and again and finally I think I found a good workaround until browsers support `import`. I considered to not open this issue as I found a (not so good way – basically just concatenating the JS files) workaround.
I just opened it to now let you know of that new browser feature. Maybe you can adjust your modules or so, if they are needed.
Or, as said, just close this issue. :smiley:

title: Clarify _.union example in docs
Question on reducing bundle size with lodash-es
body:
I've just read [this article](https://nolanlawson.com/2018/03/20/smaller-lodash-bundles-with-webpack-and-babel/) by Nolan Lawson about reducing the size of lodash in your bundle and want to make sure I understand it correctly and how to implement some of the suggestions. 

Currently the vast majority of my codebase uses the
 `import {map, values, find, isNil} from 'lodash';` format. 

My understanding of lodash-es is that I can replace my current lodash package with lodash-es 
( so `npm uninstall --save lodash` and `npm install --save lodash-es` )  and then simply add `-es` to all of my import statements and I will get the benefit of smaller import sizes as I would if I wrote my imports as 
`import map from 'lodash/map';`
`import values from 'lodash/values';`
`import find from 'lodash/find;'`
`import isNil from 'lodash/isNil';`  

Is my understanding correct?
